title-group.article-title: A New Measure of State Government Ideology, and Evidence that Both the New Measure and an Old Measure Are Valid

abstract.p: We modify Berry et al.’s congressional-delegation-based measure of state government ideology to construct a new measure—which we call the state-legislative-based state government ideology measure—by relying on Shor and McCarty’s National Political Awareness Test common space estimates of the ideal points of U.S. state legislators. We conduct tests of convergent and construct validity for the two measures. We find that they correlate highly in each year for which the state-legislative-based indicator is available (1995–2008), and when observations are pooled across all years. We also replicate numerous published studies assessing the impact of state government ideology using each indicator of ideology and find that the two measures nearly always yield similar conclusions about the effect of government ideology. Because the state-legislative-based measure is based on more direct estimates of the ideal points of state legislators than is the congressional-delegation-based measure—which uses estimates of ideal points for members of Congress from the same state as a proxy—we believe the state-legislative-based measure is superior, and we recommend that scholars use it when it is available for the state-years being studied. Because our empirical evidence indicates that Berry et al.’s congressional-delegation-based measure is also valid—and it is available for a much longer period (annually beginning in 1960)—we advise that it be used when the state-legislative-based measure is not available.

body.p: William Berry et al.’s (1998) indicator of state government ideology, observed annually for all states beginning in 1960, has been used widely in research.1 Berry et al. conceive of state government ideology as the ideological “center of gravity” of a state’s elected governmental institutions on a liberal-conservative continuum.2 Specifically, they define state government ideology as the weighted average of the ideological position of each of five institutional actors—(1) the Democratic delegation in the state house, (2) the Republican delegation in the state house, (3) the Democratic delegation in the state senate, (4) the Republican delegation in the state senate, and (5) the governor—where the ideological position of a legislative party delegation is defined as the central tendency of the ideal point of its members. Lacking data about the ideal points of state-elected officials comparable across states and time, Berry et al. (1998) estimate the ideological position of the five institutional actors by assuming that in each year, the mean position of each party delegation in a state legislative chamber and the position of each governor equal the mean position of the state’s congressional delegation from the same party, as measured by interest group (Americans for Democratic Action [ADA] and AFL-CIO Committee on Political Education [COPE]) ratings.

William Berry et al. (2010) modify the original (1998) state government ideology indicator by using Poole’s (1998) first-dimension NOMINATE common space coordinates for members of Congress instead of ADA/COPE interest group ratings to estimate the position of the five institutional actors. Berry et al. (2010, 117) argue that the resulting NOMINATE measure of state government ideology is “marginally superior” to the original ADA/COPE measure of state government ideology both on conceptual grounds and based on empirical tests of construct validity.3 Nevertheless, the NOMINATE measure also relies on information about the ideal points of members of Congress rather than those of state legislators and governors. The indicator undoubtedly could be improved if more direct estimates of the ideological positions of state institutional actors could be employed.

Shor, Christopher Berry, and McCarty (2010) take an important step toward facilitating this objective. These scholars estimate the ideal points of American state legislators by using roll call data for several types of “bridge actors,” including state legislators who were later elected to Congress. However, the utility of the resulting ideal point estimates—which we call bridge-based common space scores—in constructing a better measure of state government ideology is limited by the fact that scores are available for only 11 states over a nine-year period. Fortunately, a recent article by Shor and McCarty (2011) employs an alternative methodology to produce estimates of ideal points for state legislators that are available for nearly all states in at least some years. These estimates—which we call NPAT common space scores—are constructed using data from Project Votesmart’s National Political Awareness Test (NPAT) survey of state and federal legislative candidates, along with congressional and state legislative roll call voting data.

We take advantage of Shor and McCarty’s contribution by constructing—for each state-year for which NPAT common space scores are available—a state government ideology indicator identical to Berry et al.’s 2010 NOMINATE government ideology indicator except that it substitutes median NPAT common space scores within party delegations in state legislative chambers for mean NOMINATE scores within party delegations in Congress when computing ideology scores for the five institutional actors. We call the new state government ideology measure computed from NPAT common space scores the state-legislative-based state government ideology indicator; in contrast, we call Berry et al.’s (2010) NOMINATE measure of state government ideology the congressional-delegation-based state government ideology indicator.4

Although we view NPAT common space scores as the best estimates to date of state legislators’ ideal points, these scores are not perfect; they are estimated from survey responses and roll call data, and undoubtedly contain some measurement error.5 Thus, the validity of the state-legislative-based state government ideology indicator is not assured, and must be established. In a classic paper from the psychometrics literature, Campbell and Fiske (1959, 83) appropriately conceive of validity “as the agreement between two attempts to measure the same [concept] through . . . different methods.” Because the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based state government ideology indicators rely on far different methodologies for estimating the ideological positions of state legislative party delegations, we can test the convergent validity of the new state-legislative-based state government ideology measure—and provide a new test of the validity of the extant congressional-delegation-based state government ideology measure—by determining the extent of agreement between scores on the two measures. Indeed, we find that scores on the two indicators of state government ideology correlate quite highly. We also find evidence of construct validity; across a variety of econometric models in which state government ideology is an independent variable and an aspect of state policy is the dependent variable, a model employing the congressional-delegation-based government ideology indicator tends to yield a similar conclusion about the effect of ideology as a model employing the state-legislative-based measure. These results suggest that both the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based measures of government ideology are valid indicators of their shared underlying concept. We recommend that state politics scholars use the state-legislative-based measure of state government ideology whenever this indicator is available for the state-years being analyzed, and use the congressional-delegation-based measure—which is observed for all states over a much longer time period—when the state-legislative-based measure is unavailable.

sec.title: Defining State Government Ideology
sec.p: Berry et al. (1998) define the ideology of a state government, i, in a year, t—to be denoted state government ideologyi,t—as a weighted average of the ideological position of five institutional actors: (1) the Democratic delegation in the state house, (2) the Republican delegation in the state house, (3) the Democratic delegation in the state senate, (4) the Republican delegation in the state senate, and (5) the governor. A party’s share of power within a chamber—power:dem_housei,t, power:rep_housei,t, power:dem_senatei,t or power:rep_senatei,t—is a nonlinear, but nondeclining, function of the share of seats it controls.6 The constants in equation 1—0.25, 0.25, and 0.50—reflect an assumption that the governor and the legislature are equally powerful, and that within the legislature, the two chambers have equal strength.7

sec.title: The Congressional-Delegation-Based and State-Legislative-Based Measures of State Government Ideology
sec.p: To construct the congressional-delegation-based measure of state government ideology for each year beginning in 1960, Berry et al. (2010) use readily accessible data about party seat shares to calculate the four “power share” variables (power:dem_housei,t, power:rep_housei,t, power:dem_senatei,t, and power:rep_senatei,t) in Equation 1. Lacking direct information about the ideal points of state legislators and governors, Berry et al. (2010) estimate the ideological position of each of the five institutional actors (the variables ideol:dem_housei,t, ideol:rep_housei,t, ideol:dem_senatei,t, ideol:rep_senatei,t, and governor’s ideologyi,t in Equation 1) by assuming that the mean ideology of each party delegation in a state legislative chamber and the ideology of each governor equal the mean ideology of a state’s congressional delegation from the same party, as measured by first-dimension NOMINATE common space coordinates (Poole 1998).

The new state-legislative-based state government ideology indicator is identical to the congressional-delegation-based indicator of state government ideology except that we substitute median NPAT common space scores within party delegations in state legislative chambers for average NOMINATE scores for party delegations in Congress when computing ideology scores for the five institutional actors in Equation 1.8 We are able to construct the state-legislative-based measure of state government ideology for all state-years for which Shor and McCarty (2011) report NPAT common space scores for state legislators; the measurement period is 1995 to 2008, with a different number of states observed in different years: 49 states in 1998, 2000, and 2002; 48 in 2001; 47 in 1999; 46 in 1997 and 2005; 45 in 2003; 44 in 2006; 43 in 2004; 31 in 2007; 30 in 2008; and 12 in 1995.9

sec.title: The Validity of the State-Legislative-Based and Congressional-Delegation-Based State Government Ideology Indicators
sec.p: The state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based state government ideology indicators rely on quite different information to measure the ideology scores of the five institutional actors in Equation 1. The congressional-delegation-based measure is based on first-dimension NOMINATE common space coordinates derived from roll call votes by members of the Congress. The state-legislative-based state government ideology indicator too takes into account roll call votes by members of the Congress, but it also relies on roll call votes by state legislators, and NPAT survey responses by both state legislators and members of the Congress.

The fact that the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based state government ideology indicators rely on quite different information to measure the ideology scores of institutional actors allows us to assess the validity of the two indicators by conceiving of validity—as do Campbell and Fiske (1959, 83)—“as the agreement between two attempts to measure the same [concept] through . . . different methods,” and determining the extent of agreement between the two indicators. In particular, we assess the convergent validity of the two measures by examining the correlation between them. We also conduct a number of tests of construct validity by determining whether the two measures yield similar conclusions about the impact of state government ideology on state public policy in a variety of econometric models.

sec.title: Convergent Validity: The Correlation between the State-Legislative-Based and Congressional-Delegation- Based State Government Ideology Indicators
sec.p: The state-legislative-based state government ideology indicator is available for 587 state-years during the 1995–2008 period, and the congressional-delegation-based measure is also available for each of these state-years. Because virtually all studies using the congressional-delegation-based measure of state government ideology either are cross-sectional or pool cross-sections over a period of years, we compare scores on the two measures in both these observational domains. For each year between 1995 and 2008, the cross-sectional correlation between the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based government ideology indicators is between 0.76 and 0.89, averaging 0.81 across the 14 years. (Complete year-by-year results can be found in column 2 of Table S-1 in our unpublished supplement.) Pooling observations across all 587 state-years, the correlation between the state-legislative-based measure and the congressional-delegation-based measure is 0.81.10

However, state politics scholars often estimate a fixed-effects model—with dummy variables for the states—when doing pooled cross-sectional time-series analysis. This approach makes it so that parameter estimates for all but the state dummy variables are based solely on variation within states. The overall pooled correlation between the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based measures of government ideology—while large (at 0.81)—does not necessarily imply a high probability that the two measures of government ideology will yield the same conclusion about the effect of ideology when this effect is estimated using a fixed-effects model; it is possible that when cross-sectional variation is eliminated from the picture by including a set of state dummy variables, the close correspondence between the two measures would disappear. To investigate this possibility, we recompute the correlation between the two measures of state government ideology after scores on both measures are transformed to deviations from their within-state mean. The correlation remains very strong—at 0.85. Summarizing the results of this section, in the domains in which research is typically performed—either cross-sectional or pooled cross-sectional time-series analysis—the two indicators of state government ideology share much variation.

sec.title: Construct Validity: Do the State-Legislative-Based and Congressional-Delegation-Based State Government Ideology Indicators Yield Similar Conclusions in the Research Setting?
sec.p: The strong correlation between the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based state government ideology indicators suggests that the two measures—when used in empirical research—are likely to yield similar conclusions about the impact of government ideology on state public policies. But it would be valuable to see whether this actually occurs in the research setting. Obviously, we cannot observe the implications of using one measure rather than the other in the full “population” of all past and future studies of the impact of state government ideology. However, we can observe these consequences in a large, reasonably representative sample from the population of past studies employing the congressional-delegation-based measure by replicating these studies, substituting the state-legislative-based measure of state government ideology for the congressional-delegation-based measure.11
To maximize the probability that our sample of studies for replication is representative of previous published work, we undertook the following steps:

list-item.p: We examined all articles in the ISI database that cite Berry et al. (1998) to identify the population of studies using the (NOMINATE) congressional-delegation-based or ADA/COPE state government ideology measure in empirical research.

Because the state-legislative-based state government ideology measure is available for at least 30 states only for years during the period 1996–2008, we retained in our sample only those studies doing (1) cross-sectional analysis for a year between 1996 and 2008; (2) pooled cross-sectional time-series analysis for years, all of which are between 1996 and 2008 (regardless of the number of years analyzed); or (3) pooled cross-sectional time-series analysis over a set of years containing at least four during the period 1996–2008.12 (Due to the limited number of state-years for which the state-legislative-based indicator is available, this step reduced the pool of eligible studies dramatically.)
We searched the internet for replication data for each study in this sample. If we were unsuccessful, we emailed the author and requested replication data.

For each study in the sample for which we were able to obtain data, we sought to replicate the published results for each model that included state government ideology as an independent variable. If we were unsuccessful for any model, it was eliminated from our sample.

sec.p: This left us with 26 econometric models from seven different articles (Avery and Peffley 2005; Martin and Dixon 2010; Provost 2003; Soss, Fording and Schram 2008; Witko 2007; Witko and Newmark 2005, 2010): 10 models estimated using cross-sectional data, and 16 estimated with pooled cross-sectional time-series data.13

Using all observations for which the state-legislative-based government ideology indicator is available, we estimate each of the 26 models twice—once using the state-legislative-based measure, and once using the congressional-delegation-based measure.14 As the two indicators have different scales, to facilitate a comparison of results, “X-standardized” coefficients for the ideology measure are computed.15 One criterion for determining the similarity of results across measures is whether the congressional-delegation-based and state-legislative-based measures yield the same conclusion about whether the effect of state government ideology is statistically significant at the .05 level. We summarize our results below (Table S-3 in our unpublished supplement presents critical details, and Appendix S-5 in the supplement contains complete statistical results for all models estimated).

For 22 of the 26 models, the analysis using the congressional-delegation-based measure yields the same conclusion about whether the effect of government ideology is statistically significant at the .05 level as the analysis employing the state-legislative-based measure. For three other models (see rows 1, 6, and 23 of Table S-3), the estimated effect of government ideology is significant at the .05 level for one measure and at the .10 level with the other indicator. Results about statistical significance diverge substantially for only one model (see row 17); with it, the t-ratio for the state-legislative-based measure is 0.48, while that for the congressional-delegation-based measure is 2.05.

Of course, estimated effects can be statistically significant without being substantively significant (Achen 1982, 41–51). Thus, we seek to evaluate whether the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based measures yield similar conclusions about the substantive importance of the effect of government ideology. This is difficult to assess for any model without undertaking a careful analysis of the metric for the dependent variable, and the variances of variables within the estimation sample. Moreover, a comparison of estimated effect magnitudes is complicated by the fact that the two ideology measures are on different scales. Nevertheless, for any replicated model, we can compare the magnitudes of X-standardized coefficients across the two measures of state government ideology. For each of the twelve models in which the effect of the state-legislative-based government ideology measure is statistically significant at the .10 level, we calculate a value—the deviation magnitude—that reflects the extent to which the coefficient for the congressional-delegation-based measure deviates from the coefficient for the state-legislative-based measure:

where bSTATE-LEG is the coefficient for the state-legislative-based state government ideology indicator, and bCONG-DEL is the coefficient for the congressional-delegation-based measure.16 The mean deviation magnitude across the 12 models analyzed is 0.30, indicating that, on average, the coefficient for the congressional-delegation-based ideology measure differs from that for the state-legislative-based measure by 30% (see column 10 of Table S-3). This is certainly a nontrivial difference. Yet, we believe that combined with the nearly uniform agreement across the two measures about whether the effect of state government ideology is statistically significant, the mean deviation magnitude of 0.30 suggests a low likelihood that researchers would come to a fundamentally different inference about the effect of government ideology depending on which measure they employed—and indicates that the measures have strong construct validity.17

The evidence of construct validity reported thus far is based on a diverse, but unsystematically varying, set of dependent variables and observational domains. It would also be useful to investigate the construct validity of the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based measures of state government ideology in a context in which the periods analyzed could be systematically adjusted so that we can observe whether the construct validity of the measures is domain bound. Accordingly, we estimate an illustrative OLS regression model in which the dependent variable is a state’s Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefit for a four-person family. The independent variables are a measure of state government ideology (either the state-legislative-based or congressional-delegation-based measure), and three “control” variables: per capita personal income, the unemployment rate, and the poverty rate. We estimate this model cross-sectionally for each of the 13 years for which the state-legislative-based government ideology measure is observed (1996–2008). We also estimate the model pooling observations across all possible four-year periods (i.e., 1996–99, 1997–2000, . . . , 2005–08) and seven-year periods (i.e., 1996–2002, 1997–2003, . . . , 2002–08), and the full 13-year period. Pooled models are estimated alternately (1) with no dummy variables for either states or years, (2) including a set of state dummies, and (3) including a set of year dummies. This gives us 50 different regression models, each estimated using each measure of government ideology. Detailed results are presented in Table S-4 in our unpublished supplement.

Only 4 of the 50 models (i.e., 8%) produce a different result about whether the estimated effect of government ideology is statistically significant at the .05 level depending on which measure of ideology is used. In two of these cases, both coefficients are significant at the .10 level, but only one is significant at .05; in the other two—pooled analysis using state dummies over the periods 2005–08 and 2004–07—the difference in t-ratios is substantial (2.11 vs. 0.21, and 3.03 vs. 0.69).18 Across the 24 models in which the effect of the state-legislative-based government ideology measure is statistically significant at the .05 level, the average deviation magnitude (calculated according to Equation 4) is 0.40, a value similar to the average deviation magnitude of 0.30 calculated earlier. The analysis of the welfare model suggests that the construct validity of the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based state government ideology indicators is high in both cross-sectional and pooled cross-sectional time-series contexts.19

A possible objection to our tests of convergent validity is that although the two measures of state government ideology being compared differ substantially in their methodology for estimating the five institutional actor ideological position variables in Equation 1 (i.e., ideol:dem_housei,t, ideol:rep_housei,t, ideol:dem_senatei,t, ideol:rep_senatei,t, and governor’s ideologyi,t), the two measures have other elements in common that virtually guarantee that the measures have a positive correlation. In particular, they make identical assumptions—inherent in the conceptual definition of Equation 1—about the values of the four “power share” variables (power:dem_housei,t, power:rep_housei,t, power:dem_senatei,t, and power:rep_senatei,t) and the three constants (0.25, 0.25, and 0.50) reflecting the relative power of the governor and the two chambers of the legislature. We contend that these assumptions about the relative power of institutional actors inherent in the conceptual definition of Equation 1 are irrelevant to the validity of any measure of the concept. If the actual distribution of power among institutional actors is at variance with the distribution assumed by Equations 1, 2 and 3, this would imply that the concept defined in Equation 1 lacks utility, not that the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based measures of the concept are invalid.

Nevertheless, we repeat for the new state-legislative-based measure of state government ideology some sensitivity analysis Berry et al. (1998) conducted when they introduced the ADA/COPE measure of state government ideology. In particular, we compute a version of the state-legislative-based measure of government ideology in which the constants 0.25, 0.25, and 0.50 are replaced by 1/3, 1/3, and 1/3—implying that in each state, the house, the senate, and the governor share power equally. The correlation between this alternative measure of ideology and the state-legislative-based measure of state government ideology across all cases for which the measures are available is 0.99. We also construct nine alternative measures of state ideology—each using a different function to map party seat shares into power shares when computing the four power share variables—to create 10 measures overall.20 The correlation matrix showing the relationships among the 10 measures has an entry above 0.98 in each cell. These tests demonstrate that the state-legislative-based measure of state government ideology is robust to nontrivial changes in the specific assumptions inherent in Equation 1 about the distribution of power between the governor and the two houses of the legislature, and between parties within the two houses.

sec.title: Shor and McCarty’s Criticism of “Berry Component Scores”
sec.p: The evidence we report of the empirical similarity of scores on the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based measures of state government ideology may be surprising to readers of Shor and McCarty’s (2011) article. These authors compute NPAT common space chamber medians—that is, the median NPAT common space score among legislators in a chamber—and compare them to what they call “Berry component scores.” The Berry chamber scores that Shor and McCarty construct might be conceived as measures of the components of state government ideology labeled house ideology and senate ideology in Equations 2 and 3 that are aggregated along with governor’s ideology according to Equation 1 to yield state government ideology. Shor and McCarty find that NPAT common space chamber medians and Berry chamber scores are highly correlated cross-sectionally in each year for which NPAT common space chamber medians are available, but that these two variables are weakly correlated longitudinally within many state legislative chambers. This leads Shor and McCarty (2011, 543) to conclude that “Berry measures . . . are inadequate to capture trends in state ideology over time.”

Taken literally, this conclusion about “Berry measures” characterizes as invalid a variable that has never been employed in published research, as (to our knowledge) scholars using Berry et al.’s (1998, 2010) data have uniformly employed a measure of state government ideology (the [NOMINATE] congressional-delegation-based government ideology indicator, or its predecessor, the ADA/COPE measure) rather than a single component reflecting house ideology or senate ideology.21 Yet, Shor and McCarty’s results about the weak longitudinal relationship between NPAT common space chamber medians and Berry chamber scores in some states can be viewed as evidence of weak convergent validity in a longitudinal domain for indicators of house ideology or senate ideology.22 For this reason, we would be reluctant to use either Berry chamber scores or NPAT common space chamber medians as measures of house ideology or senate ideology in single-state longitudinal research.

If Shor and McCarty’s (2011) criticism of “Berry measures” as invalid is intended to extend beyond “Berry component scores” and include the congressional-delegation-based measure of state government ideology, the results reported in this paper confirm that this criticism would be unjustified. Undoubtedly, a strong correlation between Berry chamber scores and NPAT common space chamber medians would lend greater support for the validity of the congressional-delegation-based measure. But a close correspondence between these chamber-level variables is not a necessary condition for Berry et al.’s congressional-delegation-based government ideology indicator to be a satisfactory proxy for measuring state government ideology. The congressional-delegation-based measure of state government ideology is used extensively in cross-sectional and pooled cross-sectional time-series analysis, and we have seen that in these contexts, the congressional-delegation-based measure is strongly correlated with the state-legislative-based state government ideology measure.23 Also, the congressional-delegation-based and state-legislative-based measures of state government ideology tend to yield similar conclusions about the impact of state government ideology when each is used as an independent variable in multivariate analysis. Indeed, if a reader believes that Shor and McCarty’s (2011) methodology for measuring the ideal points of state legislators is valid, the evidence reported in this paper that empirical results based on the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based measures of state government ideology are very similar adds to the body of evidence presented by Berry et al. (1998, 2010) that the congressional-delegation-based measure of state government ideology is valid.

sec.title: Using “Party Proportions” to Measure State Government Ideology
sec.p: Shor, Berry, and McCarty (2010)—based on a comparison of Berry chamber scores to bridge-based common space chamber medians—“urge [scholars] to use raw party proportions instead of Berry scores” when ideology measures based on their own common space scores are not available. Shor and McCarty (2011), writing more recently, do not repeat this explicit claim. However, they do report evidence that chamber “party proportions” tend to have a “slightly” stronger longitudinal correlation with NPAT common space chamber medians than do Berry chamber scores, implicitly suggesting that raw party proportions may be superior to Berry scores as a measure of ideology. We investigate empirically the ability of “party proportions” to measure state government ideology.

We construct an indicator of state government ideology based purely on information about “party proportions” in the state legislature: the average of (1) the percentage of legislators in a state’s house that are Republicans and (2) the percentage of legislators in the state’s senate that are Republicans. We call the resulting variable the party-proportion measure of state government ideology; it is the average of the two variables analyzed by Shor and McCarty. We then investigate whether the congressional-delegation-based measure of state government ideology or the party-proportion measure of state government ideology more closely corresponds to the state-legislative-based measure of state government ideology.

We saw earlier that when we pool all 587 state-years for which the state-legislative-based state government ideology indicator has been measured, the correlation between the congressional-delegation-based and state-legislative-based government ideology measures is 0.81. Over the same observations, the party-proportion measure of state government ideology correlated considerably more weakly (at 0.66) with the state-legislative-based measure. We also saw earlier that for each year between 1995 and 2008, the cross-sectional correlation between the congressional-delegation-based and state-legislative-based measures of state government ideology is between 0.76 and 0.89, and averages 0.81 across the 14 years. Using the same observations, the cross-sectional correlation between the party-proportion measure and the state-legislative-based measure is weaker—ranging across the 14 years between 0.62 and 0.76, and averaging 0.68. (Year-by-year results can be found in column 3 of Table S-1 in our unpublished supplement.)

We also return to the 26 models from the literature involving state government ideology as an independent variable that we discussed earlier. We reported that for 23 of the 26 models, the analysis using the congressional-delegation-based measure yields the same conclusion about whether the effect of government ideology is statistically significant at the .05 level as the analysis employing the state-legislative-based measure. When one uses the party-proportion measure of government ideology, one is much more likely to obtain a conclusion that diverges from that derived using the state-legislative-based measure. These two measures yield the same conclusion about whether the effect of government ideology is statistically significant at the .05 level for only 13 of the 26 models (detailed results are in Table S-3 in our unpublished supplement.)24 Thus, we find strong empirical evidence that the congressional-delegation-based measure of state government ideology is substantially more likely than the party-proportion measure to yield results similar to what would be obtained if the state-legislative-based measure of government ideology were employed.25 This indicates that scholars who are convinced that that the state-legislative-based measure is valid would be making a mistake if they used the party-proportion measure rather than the congressional-delegation-based measure when the state-legislative-based measure is not available for the state-years being analyzed.

sec.title: Conclusion and Recommendations
sec.p: Shor and McCarty (2011) use Project Votesmart’s NPAT survey of state and federal legislative candidates, and congressional and state legislative roll call voting data to generate estimates of ideal points for state legislators. These ideal point estimates allow us to construct a new measure of state government ideology—the state-legislative-based state government ideology indicator—that we believe is superior to Berry et al.’s (2010) congressional-delegation-based measure of government ideology. We recommend that state politics scholars use the state-legislative-based indicator to measure state government ideology in future research whenever feasible.

However, tests of both convergent validity and construct validity demonstrate that the congressional-delegation-based measure of state government ideology remains a good alternative when research involves state-years for which the state-legislative-based indicator is not available. We find that the congressional-delegation-based measure has a strong correlation with the state-legislative-based measure in each year for which the state-legislative-based measure is available, and when pooling these annual observations across years. Also, we replicate numerous published studies that use the congressional-delegation-based state government ideology indicator as an independent variable; we find that when the state-legislative-based indicator is substituted for the congressional-delegation-based measure, the conclusion about whether the effect of government ideology is statistically significant at the .05 level is almost always identical to that obtained when using the congressional-delegation-based indicator.

Hopefully, NPAT common space ideal points for state legislators will be updated regularly in the future, thereby permitting the updating of the state-legislative-based government ideology measure. As the number of studies using the state-legislative-based measure of state government ideology grows, the opportunity to compare results based on the two measures will expand. If such comparisons continue to show that findings based on the two measures are similar, this will help confirm the results of studies predating the state-legislative-based measure that have relied on the congressional-delegation-based indicator.

Even for those years for which the state-legislative-based government ideology measure is available (1995–2008), there is always at least one state—and sometimes many states—that are not observed (see column 1 of Table S-1). This may leave many researchers with the choice between using the state-legislative-based measure and dropping some observations, and retaining all observations and using the congressional-delegation-based measure. We recommend that researchers in this situation conduct sensitivity analysis by estimating their model both ways to see whether the conclusions about the effect of state government ideology are consistent. If they are, the issue about which measure to use is rendered moot. Indeed, given that neither the state-legislative-based measure of state government ideology nor the congressional-delegation-based measure is perfect, it would be reasonable practice for scholars to estimate any model for which the state-legislative-based measure is available for a substantial proportion of the observations using each of the two measures separately and assess whether the results about the effect of ideology are robust.

To conclude, we consider two possible concerns about the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based government ideology measures. Shor and McCarty (2011, 531) claim that a “potential problem” of the congressional-delegation-based government ideology measure is that the scores it produces are “aggregates [that] . . . reveal little about heterogeneity, especially intra-party, within states.” This observation is undoubtedly correct, and it applies equally well to the state-legislative-based government ideology measure. We do not, however, view this as a weakness of the two government ideology indicators, because neither is intended to reveal information about intra-institutional variation in ideology. Rather, each is designed to reflect the ideological “center of gravity” of a state government’s elected institutions.

Probably the greatest source of measurement error in the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based indicators of state government ideology is the component measuring the ideal point of the governor, which is assumed to be equal to the median or mean ideal point of legislators from the governor’s party. Assuming that the governor’s ideal point is at the center of his or her party’s legislative ideological distribution undoubtedly introduces measurement error, because sometimes a governor will have a more extreme ideology. It is tempting to try to “solve” this problem by simply excluding the governor from the institutions over which ideology is aggregated to produce the state government ideology measure, and constructing the measure based just on the four legislative institutions. This would involve excluding the term for governor ideology in Equation 1 when estimating state government ideology, and changing the weight for each of house ideology and senate ideology to 0.50:

However, because the concept being measured is the center of gravity of a state government’s elected institutions—which includes the governor—aggregating over only the four components that reflect legislative institutions is mathematically equivalent to assuming that the governor’s ideal point equals the average of estimated house ideology and estimated senate ideology (as in Equation 5). This means that aggregating over just the four legislative components is equivalent to assuming that the governor’s ideal point is at the central tendency of ideology across legislators from both major political parties. This strikes us as an assumption likely to introduce even more measurement error than assuming that the governor’s ideology is at the central tendency of his or her own party.26 When constructing a measure of state government ideology, the only good way to eliminate the error introduced by estimating gubernatorial ideology from information about legislators’ ideal points would be to construct a direct measure of a governor’s ideal point within the same space that state legislators are observed, so that there is no need to rely on a proxy based on legislators’ ideal points. We hope that “bridges” sufficient to achieve such a measure of a governor’s ideal point will eventually be developed.

The paper makes reference to several tables and appendices in an unpublished supplement; this supplement is available online at http://spa.sagepub.com/. Data and Stata code necessary to replicate all findings presented in this paper and its unpublished supplement are available at the SPPQ Dataverse site (http://dvn.iq.harvard.edu/dvn/dv/sppq). The replication data and the unpublished supplement are also available at http://stateideology.com/state-ideology-data/, along with states’ scores for the new measure of state government ideology described in this paper. A rough indicator of the large number of researchers employing Berry et al.’s measure of state government ideology is evident in the citation count for the 1998 article introducing the measure; as of 12/7/2012, the paper has received 349 ISI citations (917 according to “Publish or Perish”). Table S-3 in our unpublished supplement includes citations to several specific studies using the measure.
Berry et al. (1998, 2010) conceive of the continuum for ideal points as reflecting operational ideology (or policy mood; Stimson 1991) rather than symbolic ideology (or self-identification).
However, the authors maintain that the two measures “rarely yield fundamentally different substantive conclusions” (Berry et al. 2010, 130).

Note that the state-legislative-based state government ideology measure is our own construction, but its calculation relies on median National Political Awareness Test (NPAT) common space scores within state legislative party delegations that were provided by Boris Shor. We are grateful to him for computing and sharing these medians.

Among Shor and McCarty’s (2011) assumptions that are likely to introduce some measurement error into NPAT common space scores are that (1) the ideal point of each legislator is stable over time (even when a legislator moves from the state legislature to Congress), and (2) “the NPAT survey[s] tap into the same issue dimensions that divide legislators on roll call voting” (p. 535). Another source of error is the low response rate to NPAT surveys; a “majority of state legislative incumbents answered the survey in the 1990s, but currently only about one-third do” (p. 532). Shor and McCarty (2011) claim that these sources of measurement error are not major concerns, and we believe that the authors defend this claim well.

Any party controlling more than 60% of the seats in a chamber is assumed to possess 100% of the power within that chamber. See Berry et al.’s (1998) Figure 1—reproduced in Appendix S-4 in our unpublished supplement—for the specific function mapping seat share into power share.

SPPQ reviewers offered two criticisms of Berry et al.’s (1998) conceptual definition of state government ideology: (1) it should take into account state supreme court ideology and (2) it should be based on the central tendency of the ideal points of members of a chamber rather than members of party delegations within a chamber. We respond to these criticisms in Appendix S-4 in our unpublished supplement.
The ideological position of the governor is estimated by the median NPAT common space score over all members of the state legislature from the governor’s party.
Data for the state-legislative-based state government ideology measure can be downloaded at http://stateideology.com/state-ideology-data/

Even the longitudinal correlation between the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based measures is strong in the vast majority of states. In 43 of the 49 states for which the state-legislative-based measure is available (all states except Nebraska), the time-series correlation between the two measures is positive and statistically significant (.05 level; two-tail test). Across these 43 states (i.e., all non-Nebraska states except DE, ID, MA, NY, RI, and SD), the minimum correlation is 0.66, the maximum is 0.997, and the average is 0.89 (see Table S-2 in our unpublished supplement). Researchers have rarely, if ever, used the congressional-delegation-based measure of state government ideology in a single-state longitudinal study. Our results suggest that this practice—and the use of the state-legislative-based measure in within-state time-series analysis—should definitely be avoided, especially in the six states for which the two measures of ideology strongly diverge.

We can also replicate models that have employed Berry et al.’s (1998) original ADA/COPE measure of state government ideology, separately substituting the (NOMINATE) congressional-delegation-based and state-legislative-based measures for the ADA/COPE measure.

Our initial plan was to restrict our replications to studies satisfying conditions (1) and (2), but there were so few studies satisfying condition (2) analyzing a period of three years or more that we decided to examine studies satisfying condition (3) to ensure that we would be able to compare the two measures of state government ideology in pooled analyses involving more than just a few years of data.
The econometric techniques used vary across models, and include OLS regression, binary logit, binary probit, ordered probit, GEE probit, and population-averaged negative binomial models.
For each model, at least one observation from the replication data set had to be deleted because a state-legislative-based government ideology score was not available.

An X-standardized coefficient is calculated by leaving the dependent variable in its original metric, but standardizing the measure of government ideology (i.e., linearly transforming the measure to a variable with a mean of zero and a standard deviation of one).

(1) We do not calculate a deviation magnitude for models in which the coefficient for the state-legislative-based ideology measure fails to be statistically significant because when the denominator of the ratio— bSTATE-LEG —is small, the ratio could be large even when the numerator is of trivial magnitude. Moreover, in practice, few scholars interpret the substantive significance of statistically insignificant coefficients. We chose to calculate the deviation magnitude for models in which the estimated effect of the state-legislative-based government ideology measure is statistically significant at the .10 level (one-tail test)—rather than the more common .05 level (two-tail test)—to permit averaging over a larger sample of models. (2) We lack a way of determining the implications of any specific deviation magnitude. For example, we know that in one replicated model (see row 2 of Table S-3), the magnitude of the coefficient estimate (−2.13) for the congressional-delegation-based measure is 22% smaller than that for the state-legislative-based measure (−2.73). Do both of these coefficients indicate a substantively significant effect? Do both indicate a substantively trivial effect? Or does the state-legislative-based coefficient indicate substantive significance while the congressional-delegation-based coefficient does not? We would not be comfortable making this type of assessment for the various models we replicate.

We also employ a second strategy for comparing the magnitude of the estimated effect of government ideology across the two indicators that relies on the notion of an “effect size” in the literature on meta-analysis (Cooper, Hedges, and Valentine 2010). This analysis leads to a similar conclusion as that of X-standardized coefficients; detailed results can be found in Appendix S-1 in our unpublished supplement.

Although the periods 2004–07 and 2005–08 are noteworthy in this respect, the pooled correlation over these periods between the two measures of state government ideology after values for both variables are transformed to deviations from their within-state mean are a healthy 0.83 and 0.78, respectively.

Of course, our empirical evidence is confined to the period for which the state-legislative-based state government ideology indicator has been measured: 1996–2008. We do not know whether the close correspondence between the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based measures of state government ideology would extend to earlier or more recent years. As Shor and McCarty extend their measurement of NPAT common space scores to additional years, we will be able to expand the domain over which the two government ideology indicators can be compared.
See Berry et al. (1998, 340) for a specific delineation of the alternative functions.

Moreover, Berry et al. (1998, 2010) never propose that the house ideology or senate ideology components of their indicator of state government ideology be used as measures of state ideology. Indeed, Berry et al. (1998, 333) define state government ideology in a single equation; the concept is broken into three components in our Equation 1 solely to facilitate a definition of what Shor and McCarty call a “Berry component score.”

There is evidence (see Appendix S-2 in our unpublished supplement) that Berry chamber scores and NPAT common space chamber medians have stronger convergent validity in a pooled cross-sectional time-series context.

It is not surprising that there is a stronger correspondence between the state-legislative-based and congressional-delegation-based measures of state government ideology than between NPAT common space chamber medians and Berry chamber scores. As we have seen, the two measures of state government ideology rest on a number of shared assumptions: the weights (0.25, 0.25, and 0.50) in Equation 1, and the values of the four “power share” variables (power:dem_housei,t, power:rep_housei,t, power:dem_senatei,t, and power:rep_senatei,t) in Equations 2 and 3. These shared assumptions undoubtedly contribute toward the close correspondence between the two measures of government ideology. Furthermore, to the extent that some of the error in measuring the ideological position of an institutional actor (ideol:dem_housei,t, ideol:rep_housei,t, ideol:dem_senatei,t, ideol:rep_senatei,t, or governor’s ideologyi,t) with NPAT common space scores or NOMINATE common space coordinates is random, some measurement error may dissipate when computing a weighted average of these positions to yield a measure of state government ideology.

We saw above that across the 12 models in which the effect of the state-legislative-based measure is statistically significant at the .10 level, the X-standardized coefficient for the congressional-delegation-based measure differs from that for the state-legislative-based measure by an average of 30%. Over the same 12 models, the coefficient for the party-proportion measure differs from that for the state-legislative-based measure by 79% (see Table S-3).
An analysis of the TANF benefit model discussed earlier leads to the same conclusion (see Appendix S-3 in our unpublished supplement).

If, instead, the concept of interest is the ideological center of gravity of a state’s legislature (i.e., [(0.50) house ideologyi,t + (0.50) senate ideologyi,t]), then excluding the governor’s ideology from the calculation would be appropriate. In this case, we would advocate using a modified state-legislative-based or congressional-delegation-based measure based strictly on the components of the measure that reflect legislative institutions.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: William D. Berry is Marian D. Irish Professor of Political Science at Florida State University, where he also holds the Syde P. Deeb Eminent Scholar Chair. His research and teaching focuses on public policy, state politics, and research methodology.

Richard C. Fording is Professor and Chair of the Department of Political Science at the University of Alabama. His primary teaching and research interests include public policy, race and politics, state politics, social movements, and quantitative methodology.

Evan J. Ringquist is Professor in the School of Public and Environmental Affairs at Indiana University, where he has courtesy appointments in the Department of Political Science and the West European Studies Center. His research interests include evaluating the consequences of public policies, democratic influences in the policy making process, bureaucratic behavior, state politics and policy, and quantitative methodology.

Russell L. Hanson is professor and chair of the Department of Political Science at Indiana University Bloomington, where he has taught since 1980. He is interested in American federalism and has published articles on political culture, economic development, and social policy in the American states. He also writes on American political thought, with special attention to social reform movements in the post-Civil War period.

Carl Klarner is associate professor of Political Science at Indiana State University. His research currently focuses on state legislative elections and election forecasting at all levels of government.
